Section 2.2 · Preliminaries

Formalizing Agentic Reasoning

Agentic Reasoning: A Latent-Space View

Standard approaches often conflate the agent's context with the environment state. We model the environment as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) and introduce an internal reasoning variable to expose the "think-act" structure of agentic policies.

Formal Definition

We consider the tuple (X, O, A, Z, M, T, Ω, R, γ), where:

  • X is the latent environment state space (unobservable to the agent)
  • O is the observation space (e.g., user queries, API returns)
  • A is the external action space (e.g., tool invocation, final answers)
  • Z is a reasoning trace space (e.g., latent plans, chain-of-thought)
  • M is the agent's internal memory/context space

At timestep t, the agent conditions on a history h_t = (o_1, z_1, a_1, ..., a_{t-1}). The history can be summarized by an internal memory state m_t ∈ M. We factorize the policy as:

π_θ(z_t, a_t | h_t) = π_reason(z_t | h_t) · π_act(a_t | h_t, z_t)

This decomposition highlights the core shift in agentic systems: performing computation in Z (thinking) before committing to A (acting).

Analysis & Explanation

Why This Matters

Practical Implications

The separation of "thinking" (Z) from "acting" (A) is what enables techniques like Chain-of-Thought, ReAct, and reflection. The agent can reason internally before committing to external actions, allowing for planning and self-correction.
